Comments: This response provides a comprehensive analysis of plastic waste production and recycling methods.  It covers linear and logistic regression for waste prediction, detailed models for drop-off and curbside collection, including cost analysis and PAYT programs, and extends the analysis to a national level.  The document is well-organized, clearly written, and uses a variety of sources to support its assumptions and calculations.

Q1.Definition: Predict the change in plastic production rate over time, as well as the amount of plastic waste in landfills in the year 2023.
Assumption: We used data collected from the past ten years because the first plastic bottle was introduced in 1975 \[11\], and recycling has only become important recently. In other words, values used before 2000 would not adequately take into account the recycling methods which have now become widespread.
Model: Discarded Plastic Waste (thousands of tons) \= 463.27 \* (years since 2000\) \+ 24443.6; R2 \= .803; S \= 801.
Discarded Plastic Waste (thousands of tons) \= 23733.8 \+ (28014.1 \- 23733.8) / (1 \+ exp((Years since 2000 \- 2.71325) / \-0.752611)). S \= 422.
Q1.Results: Based on this model, the amount of unrecycled plastic waste discarded in 2023 will be 463.27 \* 23 \+ 24443.6 \= 35098.81 thousands of tons, or 35.1 million tons.
Q1.Sensitivity Analysis: Not explicitly performed for Q1, but the comparison of linear and logistic models serves as a form of sensitivity analysis.
Strength and Weakness: Strength: Considers both linear and logistic models, acknowledging the limitations of each.
Strength: Provides clear equations and explanations of the models.
Weakness: The linear model may overpredict future values, while the logistic model may underpredict by assuming a leveling off.

Q2.Definition: Analyze the recycling method a city should develop, using as sample points the cities of Fargo, North Dakota; Price, Utah; and Wichita, Kansas.
Assumption: City shape can be approximated as a square or diamond.
The streets of the city are laid out in a grid.
There is no overlap between use of drop-off centers and curbside collection.
The composition of recyclables in the MSW stream is fixed over the entire planning horizon.
Each household makes a collective decision on whether or not to recycle because it is convenient for a household to transport all of their recyclables to a drop-off center together.
The probability of a household's deciding to recycle varies linearly with the household's distance to the nearest drop-off center.
Recycling households recycle all recyclable waste.
The available data from Ohio are representative of the U.S. as a whole.
Recycling households make biweekly trips to a drop-off center.
Model: Drop-off Centers: A simulation that randomly simulated the number of households who would recycle when drop-off centers were placed around the city.  Calculated taxicab distance, household maximum distance to a drop-off center, number of recycling households covered by a drop-off center, annual amount recycled, drop-off center cost, revenue generated, and Pay-As-You-Throw revenue.

Curbside Collection: Calculated the number of trucks needed to service a given city, based on population density. Calculated the costs of a curbside collection program based on labor, upkeep, and fuel. Determined net revenue generated by these products.
Results: Drop-off: Fargo and Wichita generate profits, Price incurs costs.
Curbside: Fargo and Price incur costs, Wichita generates profits.
PAYT: Can generate additional revenue for all cities, particularly useful for offsetting costs in Price.
Q2.Sensitivity Analysis: Tested the sensitivity of the drop-off center simulation by changing population and area by \+/- 2%, 5%, and 10% and examined the resulting change in annual amount recycled.  Found that the annual amount recycled responds approximately linearly to both area and population.
Strength and Weakness: Strength: Detailed and comprehensive models for both drop-off and curbside collection.
Strength: Considers various factors such as distance, population density, cost of operation, and revenue generation.
Strength: Uses real-world data and formulas.
Weakness: Relies on several assumptions, such as uniform population density and consistent recycling behavior.
Weakness: The drop-off center model assumes that the data from Ohio is representative of the entire U.S.

Q3.Definition: Provide recommendations for developing recycling methods on the national level based on the model we designed.
Q3.Assumption: Implicit assumption that the models developed for specific cities can be generalized to the national level.
Q3.Model: A computer simulation generating an image of all the counties of the U.S., where blue dots on the U.S. map represented counties where at least one of our three proposed recycling programs earned a net profit.
Q3.Results: In general, we recommend that the EPA extend recycling program guidelines to the national level. Small cities tend to incur net costs, while larger cities may profit.
Q3.Sensitivity Analysis: Not explicitly performed for the national-level recommendation.
Strength and Weakness: Strength: Provides a clear visual representation of the national-level analysis.
Strength: Offers a general recommendation based on the city-level models.
Weakness: The national-level model is a simplification and may not capture all the nuances of different regions.
Weakness: Lacks specific details on how the national-level model was implemented.
